If A has a basis of eigenvectors v_1,\cdots,v_n, explain how to find a matrix Q such that the matrix Q\inv AQ is diagonal. Is such Q uniquely determined by A?

Suppose you are given n \times n matrices A and Q such that Q\inv AQ is a diagonal matrix with diagonal entries d_1,\cdots,d_n. Explain how to find the eigenvalues and a basis of eigenvectors for A without any computation.

Let A be an 6 \times 6 matrix that has eigenvalues 2, 3, 1 whose eigenspaces E_2, E_3, E_1 have dimensions 2, 1, 3 respectively? Explain why A is diagonalizable and how to find a basis of eigenvectors of A.
Give an example of a 2 \times 2 matrix that is not diagonalizable even though all of its eigenvalues are real.

Give an example of a diagonalizable 2 \times 2 matrix that is not symmetric. (Hint: let A = PDP\inv where P is upper triangular but not diagonal, and D is diagonal. Then A would be also upper triangular, but probably not diagonal).

Let A be an n \times n matrix. Which of the following statements are equivalent to the statement that A is diagonalizable over the real numbers?
A is similar to a diagonal matrix.
A has at least one eigenvector for each eigenvalue.
For each real eigenvalue \lambda of A,the dimension of the \lambda-eigenspace is equal to the algebraic multiplicity of \lambda.
A has n linearly independent eigenvectors.
A is invertible.

answer.p: 1 and 4. A matrix by definition has at least one eigenvector for each eigenvalue. In option 3, a matrix need not have any real eigenvalues. Invertibility is unrelated to diagonalizability.
